coverage: Full, expanded Jonah: prophet (Amittai; Jeroboam II backdrop); divine/cosmic agents; ship scene (captain, sailors, lots, confession); descent & prayer (Sheol, bars, roots, weeds, temple, vow); Nineveh’s repentance (king, nobles, decree, animals, turning from violence); Jonah’s anger & dialogue (booth, plant joy, anger, rhetorical question, 120k, animals); geography; theology; structures; intertexts & reception; historical frame; fine-grain motifs.
id_scheme: Cross-book stable by (type+primary-slug) + deterministic hash; reuses prior IDs when names/types match.

entries: Each cried to his own god
Bars of the earth closing forever
Those who cling to worthless idols
120,000 who do not know right from left
Fear progression (afraid → exceedingly afraid → fear YHWH greatly)
Vomiting of Jonah by the fish
Who knows? God may turn and relent

entries.name: Jonah son of Amittai
entries.blurb: Prophet whose earlier ministry supported Jeroboam II’s expansion (2 Kgs 14:25). In this book he becomes an ironic anti‑prophet, fleeing God’s mercy mission to Nineveh.

entries.name: Amittai
entries.blurb: Jonah’s father; name means ‘truth/faithfulness.’ Roots Jonah’s identity in Israel’s story.

entries.name: Jeroboam II (backdrop)
entries.blurb: Israelite king in whose reign Jonah earlier prophesied. Prosperity without justice frames Jonah’s later resistance to mercy for enemies.

entries.name: YHWH (the LORD)
entries.blurb: Divine protagonist who appoints wind, storm, fish, plant, worm, and wind; relents from disaster and catechizes the prophet in compassion.

entries.name: Great wind
entries.blurb: Commissioned to hurl a storm at the sea—creation obeys.

entries.name: Great storm on the sea
entries.blurb: Chaos harnessed by God to reroute the runaway prophet.

entries.name: Great fish
entries.blurb: Womb/tomb where Jonah is kept three days; crucible for the psalm of thanksgiving.

entries.name: Plant (qîqāyōn)
entries.blurb: Gifted shade that delights Jonah before God removes it to expose his skewed compassions.

entries.name: Worm
entries.blurb: Small agent with big assignment—undoes Jonah’s comfort to provoke reflection.

entries.name: Scorching east wind
entries.blurb: With the sun, intensifies Jonah’s discomfort—embodied pedagogy.

entries.name: Sea
entries.blurb: Symbol of chaos that yet serves salvation: it threatens, then yields Jonah at God’s word.

entries.name: The ship (personified)
entries.blurb: ‘The ship thought to break’—the vessel becomes a character sharing the crew’s peril.

entries.name: Captain of the ship
entries.blurb: Importunes Jonah to call on his god; pagan captain models urgency the prophet lacks.

entries.name: Sailors/crew
entries.blurb: Polytheists who ultimately fear YHWH, sacrifice, and make vows—Gentile piety contrasts Jonah’s stubbornness.

entries.name: Each cried to his own god
entries.blurb: Religious pluralism at sea—until the true Maker of sea and land is confessed.

entries.name: Casting lots
entries.blurb: Ancient discernment rite; lot falls on Jonah, displaying sovereignty over chance.

entries.name: Hurling cargo into the sea
entries.blurb: Economic self‑loss to preserve life; sailors’ prudence anticipates their eventual sacrifice to the LORD.

entries.name: Jonah asleep in the hold
entries.blurb: Prophet’s torpor mirrors spiritual avoidance; contrasted with sailors’ wakeful prayer.

entries.name: Jonah’s self‑description
entries.blurb: ‘Hebrew; I fear YHWH, Maker of sea and dry land’—orthodox confession without obedient praxis.

entries.name: Sailors fear, sacrifice, and vows
entries.blurb: Post‑calm worship: Gentile conversion scene prefigures Nineveh’s repentance.

entries.name: Sheol (realm of the dead)
entries.blurb: Jonah cries from Sheol—poetic death—and is heard; grace reaches below rock bottom.

entries.name: Bars of the earth closing forever
entries.blurb: Imprisonment image: gates of death closed; God breaks them open.

entries.name: Roots of the mountains
entries.blurb: Mythic geography—Jonah sinks to earth’s foundations before being lifted.

entries.name: Deep, waves, breakers, flood
entries.blurb: Chaos waters as agents of judgment; yet they obey God’s summons to deliver.

entries.name: Weeds wrapped around head
entries.blurb: Seaweed like a burial shroud; emblem of entanglement in death.

entries.name: Temple as prayer locus
entries.blurb: Orientation toward God’s holy temple anchors hope in exile from land and life.

entries.name: Thanksgiving vow
entries.blurb: Vowed sacrifice and praise: ‘Salvation belongs to the LORD’—the psalm’s thesis.

entries.name: Those who cling to worthless idols
entries.blurb: Polemic against idolatry in a Gentile setting—ironically, Gentiles in story repent while Jonah resists.

entries.name: Nineveh, great city
entries.blurb: Assyria’s capital described as ‘exceedingly great’—its size underscores the scale of God’s mercy.

entries.name: A day’s journey proclamation
entries.blurb: Jonah’s minimal sermon—five Hebrew words—yet explosive effect: Nineveh believes God.

entries.name: People of Nineveh
entries.blurb: From greatest to least, they fast and don sackcloth—mass repentance unparalleled in the Twelve.

entries.name: From greatest to least
entries.blurb: Social totality formula highlighting comprehensive response.

entries.name: King of Nineveh
entries.blurb: Performs royal humility: rises, removes robe, covers in sackcloth, sits in ashes.

entries.name: Nobles/council of Nineveh
entries.blurb: Elite partner with king to enact repentance law; top‑down endorsement of bottom‑up movement.

entries.name: Animals of Nineveh
entries.blurb: Beasts share fast and sackcloth—comic yet profound sign that creation joins repentance.

entries.name: Proclamation/decree of repentance
entries.blurb: Legal text commanding abstinence, prayer, and turning from violence; hopes God may relent.

entries.name: Turning from violence (ḥāmās)
entries.blurb: Ethical dimension of repentance: not only ritual fasting but social reform.

entries.name: God relents of disaster
entries.blurb: Divine freedom to forgive upon genuine turning—conditional prophecy at work.

entries.name: Jonah’s prayer of anger
entries.blurb: Cites Exod 34:6’s mercy creed as grievance—Jonah resents grace to enemies.

entries.name: Jonah’s booth (shelter)
entries.blurb: Prophet builds a booth outside the city, hoping for fire from heaven—anti‑festival posture.

entries.name: Jonah’s joy over the plant
entries.blurb: First recorded joy—rooted in shade, not salvation—reveals malformed loves.

entries.name: Anger at the plant’s death
entries.blurb: Misdirected pity: Jonah pities the plant but not people; God exposes the dissonance.

entries.name: God’s rhetorical question
entries.blurb: Climactic appeal to divine pity for 120,000 morally ignorant persons and many animals.

entries.name: 120,000 who do not know right from left
entries.blurb: Possibly children or morally untaught populace; they anchor the case for mercy.

entries.name: Animals included in compassion
entries.blurb: Divine pity explicitly extends to livestock—creation theology meets mission.

entries.name: Joppa (port)
entries.blurb: Where Jonah embarks to flee; geography of disobedience.

entries.name: Tarshish (westward horizon)
entries.blurb: Mythic far west (Spain/Sardinia/Carthage proposals)—symbol for evasion of mission.

entries.name: Nineveh (Assyria)
entries.blurb: Imperial capital infamous for cruelty; becomes site of exemplary repentance.

entries.name: Open sea
entries.blurb: Stage for storm, confession, and divine rescue; chaos becomes catechist.

entries.name: Flight from presence of YHWH
entries.blurb: Jonah’s theology of escape collapses before God’s omnipresence.

entries.name: YHWH appoints creation
entries.blurb: Fish, plant, worm, wind—creatures become teachers under divine command.

entries.name: Universal repentance (sailors + Nineveh)
entries.blurb: Gentiles respond faster and fuller than the prophet; mission reframed as God’s pursuit of the nations.

entries.name: Divine relenting
entries.blurb: God’s freedom to forgive when violence ceases; prophecy as invitation not fatalism.

entries.name: Prophet’s nationalism vs. God’s compassion
entries.blurb: Book exposes parochial piety; God’s pity outstrips human tribalism.

entries.name: Mercy to animals
entries.blurb: Final line broadens the circle of care to creatures—Edenic aftertaste.

entries.name: Irony & satire
entries.blurb: Genre tools sharpen the question: will God’s people share God’s heart?

entries.name: ‘Great’ motif (gādôl)
entries.blurb: Refrain of greatness—storm, fish, city, anger—accentuates scale and irony.

entries.name: ‘Arise, go’ repetition
entries.blurb: God recommissions Jonah verbatim—mission persists after failure.

entries.name: Descent motif
entries.blurb: Down to Joppa, into ship, down into hold, into sea, into fish—spiritual gravity diagram.

entries.name: Chiastic parallels
entries.blurb: Ch.1 sailors ↔ Ch.3 Ninevites; Ch.2 thanks ↔ Ch.4 anger; mercy frames the plot.

entries.name: Ending with a question
entries.blurb: Pedagogical closure invites readers to answer with their lives.

entries.name: Exodus 34:6 echoed
entries.blurb: Jonah quotes the mercy creed (‘gracious and merciful, slow to anger, abounding in steadfast love’) to protest God’s character—satire with theology.

entries.name: Psalm echoes in Jonah’s prayer
entries.blurb: Lines resonate with Psalms 3, 18, 30, 42, 69, 118, 120—Jonah prays Israel’s songbook from the deep.

entries.name: Sign of Jonah (NT reception)
entries.blurb: Jesus uses Jonah’s three days as type of his death/resurrection; Nineveh’s repentance condemns an unrepentant generation.

entries.name: Yom Kippur reading (Jewish)
entries.blurb: Jonah read annually to summon repentance (teshuvah) and highlight God’s reluctance to punish.

entries.name: Islamic tradition: Yunus
entries.blurb: Parallel narrative of Yunus reinforces divine deliverance through repentance.

entries.name: Early Christian art (catacombs)
entries.blurb: Jonah vomited from fish becomes a resurrection icon—baptismal and funerary symbol.

entries.name: Assyria as empire
entries.blurb: Known for brutal warfare and mass deportations; Nineveh’s repentance therefore shocks and instructs Israel.

entries.name: Prophetic contrast: Amos & Nahum
entries.blurb: Amos condemns injustice; Nahum later announces Nineveh’s fall—Jonah sits ironically between, spotlighting mercy.

entries.name: Polytheistic pantheons at sea
entries.blurb: ‘Each cried to his god’ reflects Mediterranean religious plurality before YHWH is confessed as Maker.

entries.name: Lots as divination
entries.blurb: Practice appears elsewhere (Lev 16; Prov 16:33; Acts 1:26); Jonah shows providence guiding the lot.

entries.name: Hurl motif (God, sailors)
entries.blurb: ‘Hurl’ repeats: God hurls wind; sailors hurl cargo and Jonah—verbal choreography of surrender and control.

entries.name: Fear progression (afraid → exceedingly afraid → fear YHWH greatly)
entries.blurb: Narrative scales fear into worship; terror matures into reverence.

entries.name: Sacrifice and vows of sailors
entries.blurb: Response pattern of conversion—ritual confirms new allegiance.

entries.name: Vomiting of Jonah by the fish
entries.blurb: Comic exodus onto dry land—creation becomes midwife to mission.

entries.name: Five-word sermon
entries.blurb: Minimal proclamation maximizes divine effectiveness—Word outruns the messenger.

entries.name: Sackcloth for humans and animals
entries.blurb: Total abstinence and attire ritualize grief—repentance becomes public pedagogy.

entries.name: Ashes as throne
entries.blurb: King descending to ashes inverts royal symbolism—humility enthroned.

entries.name: Who knows? God may turn and relent
entries.blurb: Hopeful humility replaces presumption—repentance without guarantees.

entries.name: Exceedingly angry (Jonah)
entries.blurb: Superlative anger frames the final lesson—prophet’s emotions under examination.

entries.name: Pity (ḥûs) wordplay
entries.blurb: God’s ‘pity’ contrasts Jonah’s—lexical hinge of the book’s ethic.
